reviewText: Thundercats was one of my favorite shows as a child, and though I grew older, I remained convinced that "Thundercats" was a totally awesome show, matched only by the likes of "She-Ra," "He-Man," and "G.I. Joe."Well, at some point, Cartoon Network began airing reruns of "Thundercats," and if I'd chance upon an episode, I'd watch for 10 minutes or so, expecting to be entertained and reminded of my childhood love for the gang of cat-people and their heroic adventures.Unfortunately, despite my best efforts, all I could muster was a profound confusion as to how I could have been so oblivious to this show's wretchedness, despite my having been only 6 years old when I had loved it.  I wondered if I was actually watching the same "Thundercats" I used to Crayola to life for hours in my living room.All I can say is that I grew up, and that sometimes we think things from our youth are "better" than what is produced today because it's what we most identify with.  I've seen dozens of modern cartoons much better than Thundercats (and She-Ra, He-Man, and G.I. Joe), and I'd recommend this set only to someone who has recently watched the show and knows exactly what they'll be spending their money on, or they may be sorely disappointed.
summary: I lovED this as a kid.

reviewText: I wrote this a while ago as part of a rejected idea for a media project at RMIT University;Throughout history the lion has been understood as alluding to fire and of the sun. In theogony, the Sun was a metaphor for the moment when the heroic principle shines at its brightest. Therefore, this symbol of gallantry fuses with that of the lion and of fire, an exaltation of virility and latent passion, which serves to fuel the inquisitive protagonist at the heart of the Rankin/Bass classic; Thundercats.Beyond the layers of themes that develop Thundercats' narrative (Such as sovereignty, jealously, technological evolution and justice) predominate focus is laid upon the issue of Lion-O's maturity during key episodes of the series. The plight of Lion-O is as well known as any classic fable from The Iliad to The New Testament; fleeing their home planet of Thundera, the Thundercats were in suspended animation as they headed towards their new home of Third Earth. However, during the trip Lion-O's containment pod leaked, which had caused him to age normally. Leaving Thundera as a child, he entered Third Earth... as a man.Lion-O attempted to find maturity through technology in the form of the Sword Of Omens. The weapon begins as a dagger, however, as Lion-O clasps it in his hands he yells out for the power of the Thundercats, the object grows until it has erected into a sword. The phallic undertones are self-explanatory and accurately play off the lion's impulsive desires, however the addition of lightning adds a dimension of illumination and creativity. The thunder reflects celestial fire as an active force, terrible and dynamic, and in this case it contrasts against the strength of the sword, in its power to penetrate and wound.(From [...] - Accessed Sunday 2, September 2007)However, the true nature of strength cannot rely on passion without an element of discipline and self-control. The Major Arcana Tarot Card on Strength shows the image of the calm, angelic woman petting a lion into submission. The analogy is clear; the controlled Virgo defeats the fiery Leo. In respect to Thundercats, this philosophy holds true. Lion-O's undying passion parallelling with his lack of emotional development from an absent childhood is a dangerous weakness that, fortunately, the Sword Of Omens compensates for. For when Lion-O erects the weapon, a giant signal of the Thundercats logo is projected into the sky enabling him to contact his more grounded companions and benefit from their abilities whether it's the philosophical worldview of Tygra, the technological craftsmanship of Panthro, the emotional intelligence of Cheetara and even the pessimistic yet relevant words of caution of Snarf.The idea behind Thundercats shows that to truly be a leader one must have the passion and desire to succeed along with the common sense to delegate duties to others you trust and who exceed your abilities, because remember; despite his lack of maturity, Lion-O is still the leader. Lion-O is the Lord Of The Thundercats, the heir to Claudius and earned his position through trials of strength, speed, cunning and mind power. However, without the Thundercats team, Lion-O is powerless to Mumm-ra.---With such depth like that, how can you NOT want to watch the Thundercats?

reviewText: Having been a fan of The Thundercats since 1985, I'm happy that we finally get the series on DVD. Unlike everyone else, however, I'm not going to moan about the fact that the set isn't remastered and whatnot. Why? Well- I'm an avid animation collector(if you've read alot of my reviews, you'd be aware of that). Thing is, you'd be surprised at the likes of animation that never sees the light of day on DVD. Not only that but, those who go on about its' VHS-quality, keep in mind it was made in 1985(long before digital animation that we see today). For that reason alone is why I'm not so dissatisfied. Would I have preferred for it to have been remastered? Of course. But, as things are- I'm more than happy that Thundercats is finally available.I really enjoyed this sets' episodes. It was really awesome getting reaquainted with my youth.Given that there is a new Thundercats series debuting on Cartoon Network soon, now would be a good time to get the whole series. At its' current price, it is definitely a steal.

reviewText: I've been a diehard "Thundercats" fan ever since I saw a rerun of it in the '90's when I was five years old and I love this boxset! It has my favorite character from "Thundercats", Mumm-Ra, the evil mummy wizard/demon priest, the main villain from the show. This boxset has the first half of Season One, episodes 1-33, I think, from the first episode, where the Thundercats go to Third Earth from Thundera, Jaga, their leader, sacrifices himself to save their spaceship, and Lion-O becomes the new Thundercats leader, the second episode, where the Thundercats meet, and are attacked by, Mumm-Ra and the Mutants, Slithe, Monkian, Jackalman, and Vultureman, to the one where Mumm-Ra disguises himself as a Berbil, sneaks up on the thundercats, and attacks them, to the one where Mumm-Ra disguises himself as a plant creature and tricks and attacks the Thundercats, and all of the rest of the episodes of the boxset. There's also a special feature or two as well. I love this boxset and I can't wait to get it; I own all of the other three boxsets. There aren't as much of the fantastic cartoons like this, "Voltron (Lion Voltron)", "DragonBall Z", "Pokemon", "Digimon", and many others that either had reruns in the '90's or were new shows in the '90's and were on TV then! (Also, another really good thing about the show is that, it was made by Rankin and Bass, the people who made the classic "Hobbit", "Lord of the Rings", and "Return of the King" "Lord of the Rings" cartoons and the stop-motion animation Christmas Classics, such as "Frosty the Snowman" and 'Rudolph the Red-Nosed Reindeer".)
summary: Awesome "Thundercats" DVD boxset and a classic in anime/cartoons!

reviewText: This DVD set could be so much better... Warner Bros obviously did not put effort in making this a great DVD set. I agreed with viewers that the first episode when I was watching it.. The picture on one brief scene was kinda shakey..I was like what was that?? This is the 21st century with DVD as the main digital media for the masses around the world and here I am seeing this on my DVD. I was shocked!!! The sound on the 1st episode was really blurry... It wasn't crystal clear. How could this be??? And the special features featuring fans speaking out about their beloved Thundercats cartoon was a total disaster... Those people featured was a complete shamed to watch. I was so disappointed. Couldn't Warner Bros do something better?? Get the right kind of people and put them in there..... There was no interviews with the actors who voice the charaters... We  want to see who the actors are??? Of all these years over 2 decades....It's shame that Thundercats DVD finally arrived for the masses but with disappointing quality I might add. Anyone who have not bought this DVD.. my advice is if you don't mind all the negative aspect of this DVD set.. then go ahead and get yourself a copy. If not then skip it. On the positive side.. It is always a blessing to own Thundercats DVD.. I have been looking for years since DVD format was introduced years back. To finally own it is a wonderful feeling but then again.. We are NOT SATISFIED with the MONEY that we have paid for!!!

reviewText: "In a distant galaxy, the world of Thundera is in crisis. The planet's structure has become unstable and is near collapse. With their destruction imminent, Thundera's denizens--known as the Thundercats--escape in a spaceship and plot a course for a new home. While in transit, the Thundercats are attacked by evil mutants and their craft is irreparably damaged. Jaga, the eldest Thundercat, sacrifices himself in order to pilot the ship safely to its destination: Third Earth.Upon reaching the new planet, the Thundercats--Lion-O, Panthro, Cheetara, Tygra, WilyKat, WilyKit and Snarf--must fight evil with the aid of the magic Sword of Omens. From their headquarters known as Cat's Lair, the Thundercats face off against the mutants, who have followed our heroes to Third Earth. It won't be an easy contest, because the mutants have a powerful new leader: Mumm-Ra, the Ever-Living. It's up to Lion-O and the rest of the Thundercats to restore peace to Third Earth."Wow, I'm so excited for this one.  I have been waiting for this forever as I saw show after show get released on DVD.  I grew up with this show, it it's easily in my top 5 cartoons of all time (along with he-man and GI Joe).  It only ran from 1985-1988, but it's an excellent, excellent show.  I'd really recommend picking up a copy of this as soon as it comes out.  I know that I will be.

reviewText: What's wrong with you people? Thundercats was never produced HIGH quality, and it was 1985, it was drawn on crappy animation cels, then treated badly and made into a tv show for us kids. They didn't archive the stuff, I mean this wasn't made on thick 70mm film like Star Wars, then archived, then cleaned for 15 million dollars. I have the Transformers DVD Box Set and they explain about the inferiority of 1980's materials, but that they did the best to restore the cartoons to better than original release, they even have a split screen! They also took the MONO track and made it 5.1  So stop trying to think you'll EVER get a super clear THX digitally enhanced version of ANY 1980's cartoon, this is as good as it gets folks! reviewText: First off, I purchased this set in February of 2008; after watching every episode, I didn't see any errors that were previously reported. True, these DVD's didn't get the master treatment that DVD's like "He-Man" got, but the transfer isn't horrible.I'm not sure if this is considered anime, but it certainly looks alot more like anime than "He-Man" (which resembles an American comic book). Like "He-man", Thundercats is your classic story of good VS evil.As a child this cartoon seemed very strange in a scary sort of way, probably as a result of the evil Mumra and the strange mutants. The music is also pretty sinister, but very effective. As an adult, I can appreciate this series in a whole new light. Good writing, interesting characters, great animation, fantastic music, etc.If you see this on sale (like I did), don't be afraid to buy it so you can relive the magic and share it with your children. Very fun and positive messages for children.
summary: One of the best cartoons ever

Title: N/A

reviewText: Well, apparently hell has frozen over, as we are finally getting Thundercats DVDs.  Since LJN (who produced the show) closed their doors many years ago, it seemed that the Thundercats would never see the light of day again.  I feel that the only reason these DVDs are being released at all is because of the fact that people are making an absolute killing on eBay selling pirated home-made sets of the Thundercats episodes.  I am very happy to hear that these pirates will no longer have a market for their terrible quality garbage (yeah, I bought one of these sets and the quality was abyssmal.)I, for one, am very happy to finally get this show on DVD, as it is truly one of the best animated series every produced.  Fans of the show will also enjoy hearing how good the episodes sound in stereo (I have a few commercial LJN Thundercats VHS tapes from the early 80's and the sound quality is incredible.)I guess the lesson here is that if people pirate something long  enough and make some money, someone will find a way to release the genuine article sooner or later.  I'm just glad they did.***UPDATE***  Please disregard the 5 star rating I gave this set above.  I got the set today and quckly realized that the audio is MONO.  This is such a shame, because as I said above, I do have a few commercial Thundercats VHS tapes and the stereo sound on those is awesome.  Since stereo masters of these shows obviously exist, where the hell are they?!?!?  It seems to me that they made the DVDs mono to save a little room on the discs themeselves.  Someone REALLY dropped the ball here - I just knew it was too good to be true.  I am very disappointed indeed.Also, the video quality is as bad as you've heard.  Now, I am not looking for a 5 million dollar frame-by-frame restoration of the series but the video wasn't even remastered.  I kind of thought something was up when I saw how bad the footage in the DVD commercial looked.  Basically, the video quality of these DVDs is average at best.  On my VHS tapes, the colors pop off the screen - on the DVDs, the colors are VERY muted by comparison.I have a good Super-VHS VCR and I transferred the "Exodus" VHS tape I own to DVD about a year ago (and no, I didn't sell it on eBay).  By way of comparison, the copy I made from the commercial VHS tape blows this set out of the water in both video and (especially) sound quality.  I would put clips of it up on the net somewhere if it were not for the legal issues.  Believe me, your jaw would drop.Let the buyer beware!
summary: Never thought I would see the day...
Title: N/A

reviewText: At long last, the DVD set we've all been waiting for since 1985: Thunder-Thunder-Thunder-ThunderCats!  I don't have to tell you the ThunderCats was/is/and always will be the absolute finest animated series ever produced.  Unfortunately, however, this release comes with a couple of flaws.  On the plus side, the set consists of 6 single-sided discs - not those hated "flippers" as originally reported.  The box/case art is sensational; you'll be proud to display this on your DVD shelf.  The picture quality is pretty good most of the time; the mono sound is just OK.  BUT, the most important episodes in the series, the first and the second, are botched!  In the early part of "Exodus," the picture sort of starts to roll for a few seconds while Jaga is talking to Lion-O after the destruction of Thundera.  This alone is enough to make a person think they've got a defective disc, but the most jarring glitch doesn't show up till the second episode  (for which NO TITLE appears on the screen).  Yes, fellow super-fans, it appears that Monkian was at the controls during the transfer of "Unholy Alliance" from VHS to DVD, as the version presented here is TOTALLY devoid of the familiar ThunderCat background music!  Unbelievably, the very first time we visit the tomb of the dreaded Mumm-Ra...the very first time we witness his horrific transformation from his decayed form to the terrifying "Ever Living Source of Evil"...the very first time he's sent screaming and crying back to his foul sarcophagus by the mighty Lord of the ThunderCats and his mystic Sword of Omens ...we hear NO MUSIC!  If you want to hear background music during "Unholy Alliance," you must either A: Select the Spanish-language track, B: Select the French-language track, or C: Telephone Will Wheaton and his tone-deaf friends and ask them to come over to your house and sing the ThunderCats theme out of tune for you while you watch!  This is an outrage!  My video-taped version of "Unholy Alliance" (which I recorded from Cartoon Network a few years back) has background music, and my video-taped version of "Exodus" doesn't have a rolling picture after Thundera's destruction; why should the DVD version have these problems?  With great trepidation, I watched the other 31 episodes in this set and found no major abnormalities, aside from an occasional lack of smoothness in the animation and some grain here and there.  Of course all the episodes are CLASSIC, and feature legendary characters like the Berbils; the Warrior Maidens; the Brute Men; the Unicorn Keepers; Snowman and Snowmeow; Hammer Hand; Ratar-O; Wizz-Ra; Mongor; Grune the Destroyer; Hachiman; Safari Joe; Dr. Dometome; Quick Pick; Captain Cracker; and Mandora the Evil Chaser...just to name a few.  I firmly believe that every man, woman, and child in the world should watch at least one episode of the ThunderCats every single day for their entire lives; that's why everyone needs to buy this set...despite the aforementioned glitches.  I also think that everyone who buys this set should call, write or e-mail Warner Bros. and DEMAND a corrected version of disc 1.  HOOOOOOOOOO!
summary: By Jaga! I sense Mumm-Ra's evil hand in this...

reviewText: In 1985, the famous Rankin-Bass animation studios (the guys behind Rudolph, The Hobbit and The Last Unicorn) created an original and unique animated series that became a saturday morning phenomenon called "Thundercats". It tells the story of how a group of cat-like alien humanoids called Thundarians from planet Thundarr came to Third-Earth in the future for a place to stay until a group of evil mutants and a powerful dark lord named Mumm-Ra cause mayhem on the planet. The leader Lion-O has a magic sword in which he can summon his friends like the cunning Panthro, the beautiful Cheetara, the swifty Tigra, the hilarious Snarf and the helpful thunderkittens to help him battle the forces of evil. Thus a legendary animated show was born as it ranked in that time alongside "Transformers", "G.I. Joe", "He-Man", "She-Ra", "Spider-Man and His Amazing Friends" and "Dungeons and Dragons".This DVD has 33 episodes of the first part of the first season such as the origin episode "Exodus" followed by "Unholy Alliance", "Berbils", "The Slaves of castle Plun-Darr", "Pumm-Ra", "Terror of Hammerhead", "Trouble with Time", "The Tower of traps", "The garden of Delights", "Mandora The Evil Chaser", "The Ghost Warrior", ' The Doomgaze", "Lord of the Snows", "The Spaceship Beneath the Sanda", "The Time Capsule", "The Fireballs of Plun-Darr", "All That Glitters", "Spitting Image", "Mongor", "Return to Thundera", "Dr. Dometone", "The Astral Prison, "The Crystal Queen", "Safari Joe", "Snarf Takes Up The Challenge", "Sixth Sense", "The Thunder-Cutter", "The Wolfrat", "Feliner part 1 & 2", "Mandora and the Pirates", "Return of the Driller" and "Dimension Doom".The DVD quality isn't too bad but somehow feels like a bootleg copy on the quality with the not-so bad sound and the only extra is a cool documentary that talks to fans of the show, all in all this is a masterful animated series that is a must have for animation lovers.
summary: A classic 80's show on a flawed DVD set!
Title: N/A

reviewText: I don't know why people are flipping out and saying this box-set sucks.The only thing I can agree with is that there isn't a LOT of special features, but come on. It's called Thundercats: Season 1-Volume 1. And that's exactly what it is.It has the first 33 episodes of the series featured on six discs, so that's about $1.40 for each episode.Where else are you going to get these classic cartoons?Each story has a great moral, and the animation is amazing considering the series is over 20 years old.If you're looking for some kind of new and improved, remastered, dolby surround sound DVD with 10 hours of extra features, don't bother with this set. Each episode looks just like it did on TV, and the only notable problem I had with the set was during the 1st episode, the picture kind of went off the screen for a second or two.I'm glad I got this set, and when I have kids, they can watch this instead of that "Kids Next Door, Billy and Mandy, and Ed, Edd and Eddy" garbage on tv right now.This DVD set is great, and I plan on getting the other 3 sets after I finish this one.
summary: Thundercats is back from the past.

reviewText: Thundercats is an older cartoon but is still one of best. Excellent action, plots, and animation. The characters are exaggerated real-life personalities, so almost anyone can enjoy.

reviewText: No doubt this is the best cartoon EVER. Not only has this show still stood the test of time,but it still slaps current cartoons in their less then careing animation every day.But with good comes bad.The transfers where taken off TV masters. TV Masters are what studios send to air the show on. Realistically,thats all that should exist now,because thats all that existed for the show back then. Exactally how the cel's where scanned and mashed togeather is what your seeing.Alot of people are complaining about the video and sound. The video cant be mastered. Theirs notthing really to remaster. And im happy about that,because again,your getting exctally what was on TV. They didnt tamper with it the way the He-Man box sets where.But theirs 2 huge issues right now,im sure more will be discovered.-Exodus. The video is grainy and at the 3:13 marker the video skips like nuts. Not present on the original airings or tv masters. WB goofed this up with a authoring issue.-The Tower Of Traps. - The opening untill The Wollow is saved has skipping animation. Again I believe it to be a authoring problem. Not on previous airings.BUT THE WORST PART.... THE EXTRA FEATURES!Notthing like people who cant even pronouce some of the charachters names,to remeber stuff completley wroung and sing the theme song out of tune. These ageing morons brought notthing new to the table. WB had offers from myself and other people involved in thundercats archival area's. Again,lack of careing. Wil Wheaton and the others are idiotic and make Thundercats fans seem stupid and always rooting for the good guys. Thanks.......thanks for a one sided prospective.Eighter way get it. Its a fantastic release minus the 2 glitchs so far. Lets hope WB doesnt repeate the extra's again.
summary: Best show ever,gets so-so release.....here's the deal.

reviewText: I've been a Thundercats fan since the 80s, and while the picture and audio quality of these DVDs was disappointing, I'm still thrilled that this show is now available on DVD! As many have said before, the DVD transfer is no better in quality than the original broadcast, but it is no worse either. I enjoyed it then, and I am enjoying it now. Note that Episode 2 is lacking the background music in the English language track. That was annoying! I called WB at (800) 553-6937 for a replacement disc and got it after 6.5 weeks! I was beginning to wonder if it was coming at all! But all is well that ends well and I went ahead and purchased Season 1, Part 2, which had no problems. As a final word, I don't know if the show will appeal to new viewers, but if you liked the Thundercats before, this collection is a must-buy.
summary: true fans will enjoy this cartoon classic...
Title: N/A

reviewText: Thundercats was one of the best shows to come out of the 80s (Transformers being at the top), and one every fan has been eagerly awaiting to hit DVD.Months ago, WB finally announced they would be releasing the series in a total of four box sets (33/32/33/32), which had everyone cheering for the return of one of their favories shows, in top notch DVD quality.  Most of all, they were given a SRP of $64.99, thus guaranteeing the episodes must be remastered.  Unfortunately, this is not the case.For a SRP of $64.99, you get 33 episodes on six discs, but without any remastering done whatsoever.  What was WB thinking?  Not only do the episodes look like they were dumped down from VHS tapes (giving it a bootleg quality appearance), but there are a mass amount of errors throughout the episodes themselves.  One of the major issues is with the second episode, "Unholy Alliance," which is missing all of the music (sans the opening and closing) during the episodes.  However, this is only the case in the English track as both the Spanish and French versions have the music playing.  Whatever the reason is, this is totally unacceptable.  Hopefully WB will issue a recall and offer replacement discs.The next negative to this set is that it is definitely no where near woth a SRP of $64.99.  Yes, you can buy them cheaper online or at a retail store, but if you pay more than $30-35 for this set, then you were just ripped off.  You could buy a DVD-R bootleg (not that you should) off ebay of the entire series in the same quality (if not better) for $15 more.With other 80's shows, coming out (or have already been released) with a beautiful remastered print, and 5.1 audio, this makes this buy even worse than it seemed before.  Why couldn't WB let Rhino handle this?  Rhino may have their own faults, but at least they know how to NOT mess up a release THIS bad.  Not to mention Rhino would have remastered the prints and mastera  a 5.1 track, while this just has a less-than-satisfying-and-boring mono soundtrack.So if you have not bought this set yet, hold off until WB fixes the set's glitches or lowers the SRP.  Also, let's hope they do a much better job with Volume 2 when it comes out in Dec than they did with this.  I love Thundercats, I am happy to own it on DVD and replace my tapes from Toonami, however, the price is unacceptable for a crappy release as this.WB, Thundercats deserves to be treated just with respect as you have done so with Looney Tunes, and as much as Rhino did so with Transformers!
summary: WHY WHY WHY?  Great show, but a piss poor release

reviewText: [...]Ok but as far as the dvd goes, each episode is in chronological order.  This set lacks special features, but all I ever wanted was the episodes.  And being in chronological order as they are, is more than I ever could have expected.  The quality is exactly as that of television.  Its a tv show, why do I need it to be widescreen, or digitally remastered high definition bullcrap, or surround sound?  I want to remember this show as it was, and that is exactly how it is.  It even says on the dvd "preented in a format PRESERVING the aspect ratio of its ORIGINAL television exhibition."  To me that means nothing has been added or taken away, it is exactly as I remember it, exactly how I need it.  The problem today is that everyone is spoiled with special features that they forget that before we had dvd boxsets, we had to tape them from the tv ( or cartoon network in this case) or buy the old vhs tapes.  "Special" features are "special"  and before we had dvds we had to pay 24.99 for most vhs that had only the film.  We should be thankful that we live in today where we can own a whole series on dvd for less than 200 total.  Special features are a new luxury that too many people take for granted.  I am glad that finally I will own all the thundercats episodes ever on dvd.  I never watch commentary on any dvd, so I dont need that.  All I ever wanted was the episodes, that is what I am paying for.  I dont pay for special features on any dvd and I can live without most of them which are most of the time ridiculous.  Sure I will agree that special features would have been a nice bonus, they could have put some really cool things.  I mean this is the thundercats, but I dont rate dvds on special features, I rate them on the film, or in this case the series.  I take away one star for the defect, and now I have to be inconvenienced by calling a number and sending in my disc and wait 4-6 weeks for a replacement.  Studios should put more care into these matters, previewing it before they make and sell us a bunch of defected copies.  So I give 4 stars for a great show being put into a nice box, and putting a nice picture on my tv.  Not to mention it looks great on my shelf ;)  I cant wait to own the entire series!!!  THUNDERCATS HO!!!
summary: The best 80's Cartoon to be released on DVD!!!
Title: N/A

reviewText: I want to first say that I love Thundercats. Along with gi joe and transformers, it ranks as one of the greatest cartoons of the '80s. The reason for my 1 star review has nothing to do with the show, but instead with the dvds. For such a price it really is highway robbery.The episodes look like they were taken from tv. No remastering or enhancement, you can still see white marks and scratches. Also, as mentioned in another review, the background music is missing from some episodes. Along with that, the menus are sorely lacking. They're very short and without any imagination or flair. Except for the main menu, all the submenus are just still images from the show.And don't fall for the specials. The only special you get in this volume is a 7 minute interview with fans. FANS, not the artists or the producers, but a few fans. Big deal. One further complaint, no chapters in the episodes. The entire episode is just one big chapter. At least rhino was able to split the episodes into scenes.I would swallow my pride if this cost 19.99 or thereabouts, but not for this price. The lack of detail and quality just shows all over this release; don't you just hate corporate greed.

reviewText: I said I was a huge Thundercats fan, & now it’s time I prove it.  I know it seems I keep switching back and forth on what the second best cartoon of the 80s is, but I really should have said it was this one.  I’ll never forget when I discovered this wonderful cartoon on Toonami one afternoon.  It immediately captivated my interest, & it would definitely play in my essential Toonami line-up.  I got the whole first season for Christmas of 2005, and I can always pop in the discs & count on being entertained.  Seriously, I could not believe how well it has held up for me.  The animation is great, the dialogue is good, the stories are interesting, the action is exciting and to top it all off this has one of the greatest soundtracks of any cartoon ever.  There aren’t that many American cartoons with soundtracks I would pay good money to own but this is definitely in the top 5 (Samurai Jack will be forever at the top though).  The only bad thing about it is some of the voices.  It’s not the worst voice acting I have ever heard (that dishonor goes to the English dub of Inuyasha) but it’s not the best either, though some of the voices are very good (Mum-Ra's being a definite standout).  Still, the rest of the show more than makes up for it, & now I can appreciate how epic it is for an 80s cartoon.  There’s a fair amount of continuity, & it gets even more epic during the second season (although the first season will always be my favorite, the second season was definitely worthwhile despite some glaring faults).  The characters both good and bad were all cool too, even Snarf (I’m surprised how underrated he is.  I think he’s pretty endearing.  I even think his nephew Snarfer is okay!)  Here’s a review of the episodes, with synopsizes from Wikipedia.Disc 11.  Exodus:  The ThunderCats must find a new home after their home planet, Thundera, explodes.  This is one of the single greatest first episodes ever.  I came in during the second half of the first season, but I did see this one on TV later.  It really surprised me.  A+2.  Unholy Aliance:  While exploring Third Earth, the Mutants ship, piloted by Slithe, Monkian and Jackalman, is brought down by a mysterious black pyramid; which is the home to Mumm-Ra, an evil demon who is willing to form an alliance to capture the Eye of Thundera.  With the young Lord of the Thundercats in sight, Lion-O is about to face his toughest enemy yet.  A great introduction for Mum-Ra, who is still one of the greatest villains in western animation.  A3.  Berbils:  Panthro introduces the ThunderTank, saving the others from a meteor shower conjured by Mumm-Ra that buries the remnants of the ThunderCats' ship.  Later, Lion-O and Snarf are taken prisoner by a band of small robotic bears named Ro-Bear Berbils, lead by Ro-Bear Bill and Ro-Bear Belle.  They soon learn that the Berbils are being frequently attacked by the Trolligs who steal their fruit to give to the Giantorrs.  B+4.  Slaves of Castle Pun-Darr:  The Cats Lair is nearly complete when an agitated Wilykit and Wilykat rush home to tell the other ThunderCats that the Mutants have enslaved a race of creatures called Brute Men to build their new fortress, Castle Plun-darr.  After learning more about the Brute Men from the Berbils, Tygra tells the twins to stay behind, as the adult ThunderCats rush off to free these peaceful creatures.  A5.  Pumm-Ra:  Mumm-Ra disguises himself as a Thunderian named Pumm-Ra, and claims to have rescued Cheetara from the mutants in order to infiltrate the now completed Cat's Lair.  If this episode had been done later, ti would have been stupid but since they don’t even know Mum-Ra’s name at this point it’s perfectly acceptable.  A6.  The Teror of Hammerhand:  Snarf is captured after freeing a unicorn from the pirate Hammerhand and his Berserkers who are out hunting for food. Lion-O meets the Unicorn Keepers and then sets out to free Snarf from his captors.  ADisc 27.  Trouble With Time: The Mutants are looking for a "feminine touch" around Castle Plun-darr and attempts to capture natives of the 3rd Earth.  Willa, of the Warrior Maidens is introduced, and she and her sister, Nadya, manage to fight off Monkian; but both of them are cautious of the new arrivals (i.e. ThunderCats & the Mutants).  Lion-O also takes the ThunderTank for a short-lived joyride, whilst Tygra looks for Thundrylium in a strange cave and begins to age at an accelerated rate.  An excellent episode.  A+8.  Tower of Traps: Wilykit and Wilykat meet a traveling Wolo and then go in search of a piece of stolen jewellery.  Wilykat becomes a prisoner locked up in a tower as Lion-O and Wilykit must find their way to him through a maze of booby traps, set by a mysterious being known as Baron Karnor.  Another excellent episode.  A+9.  The Garden of Delights:  Tygra chases a giant worm underground and encounters the Molemen.  After following them, he runs into Mumm-Ra, who has disguised himself as a flower named Silky.  Tygra is drugged and used against his fellow ThunderCats to steal the Sword of Omens.  Mumm-Ra and the Mutants then capture Willa the Warrior Maiden in an effort to use the Sword and destroy the ThunderCats.  Yet another excellent episode, and one of the strangest episodes of any 80s cartoon.  Just how many other shows back then dealt with characters getting addicted to drug-like substances?  A+10.  Mandora - Evil Chaser:  Lion-O finds what looks like a spaceship's escape pod, he opens it and inadvertently releases the galactic convicts Quickpick, Burnout and Plutar. Mandora the Evil Chaser is introduced and Lion-O assists her in trying to recapture the convicts; encountering the Living Ooze and the subterranean Mudhogs along the way.  A lot of people hate Mandora but I thought she was a fine character.  A-11.  The Ghost Warrior:  While searching for treasure inside an ancient tomb two Bolkins, Bundun and Hurrick, accidentally release the ghost of the evil Grune the Destroyer.  Grune knows of the ThunderCats and reveals an ancient and storied past with Jaga.  The Bolkins, Wolos and Berbils urge the ThunderCats to help them against this powerful foe.  An excellent with quite possibly the best guest villain.  A+12.  The Doomgaze:  Mumm-Ra is hatching a plot to release an ancient princess who has the power to mesmerize males with her gaze.  Another excellent episode with a memorable guest villain.  Somebody must have really liked her, since she returned in the comics.  A+Disc 313.  Lord of the Snows:  A meteor of pure Thundrillium crashes into the remote Hook Mountain. When Lion-O goes after it, he finds himself face to face with a man of the mountain whom he must fight.  A great episode that has the first appearances of the Snowman & Vultureman.  A14.  The Spaceship Beneath The Sands: After repeated defeats, the Mutants ask Mumm-Ra to return their ship which he buried in the desert around his pyramid.  Once it is resurfaced, they have new weapons to use against the ThunderCats.  The only bad thing about this episode is the animation.  A15.  The Time Capsule:  The ThunderCats decide it is time to search for their time capsule from Thundera which has been missing since the crash.  A16.  Fireballs of Plun-Darr:  The Tree Top Kingdom is attacked by fire balls launched from a new weapon inside Castle Plun-Darr. When Tygra goes to investigate, he is captured and locked into a device which will rip him apart by pulling out his four limbs. Lion-O and Willa must rescue Tygra and destroy the Mutants' new weapon.  An excellent episode.  A+17.  All That Glitters:  Mumm-Ra tricks Lion-O and Tygra into fighting each other which causes the Sword of Omens to break. In order to repair it the ThunderCats seek the help of a being whose powers are derived from bathing in liquid gold.  Another excellent episode; and one that really puts the Thundercats to the test.  A+18.  Spitting Image:  After the Driller captures Panthro, Mumm-Ra creates an evil clone of the real Panthro to turn the people of Third Earth against the ThunderCats.  It’s the old “frame the heroes” plot used in almost every cartoon ever.  There are a couple cool moments (The character of the Driller and Mum-Ra summoning the ghost of Hammerhand.  Even if it gets a retcon later, it’s surprising to see an 80s cartoon kill off a character.), but it’s still not that great.  CDisc 419.  Mongor:  While exploring, the ThunderKittens stumble across an old temple where their curiosity gets the best of them and they release a demon.  It's a goat-like creature who gets more powerful as others fear him.  It's up to the Thundercats to find a way to overcome their fears and defeat this monster.  A pretty good episode with a decent new villain.  B+20.  Return To Thundera:  The Mutants unleash a new invincible war robot while Lion-O accidentally travels back in time to Thundera when he enters the Time Capsule's hologram. There he meets his father, Claudius, who gives him a scroll containing the secret of the war robot.  One of the high points of the whole series.  A+21.  Dr. Dometone:  A frog robot swallows Wilykit. It turns out to be piloted by Dr. Dometome the scientist responsible for maintaining the ocean's plug which stops the ocean draining into the Earth's core.  This is the worst episode of the whole show.  Unlike some of the other duds, there’s nothing good about this episode at all.  F22.  The Astral Prison:  Jaga is imprisoned in the mysterious Astral World, where he is captured by the devilish Nemex.  Lion-O must journey there to free him. However, there is no way for him to return.  Much better.  A23.  The Crystal Queen:  A rare and beautiful bird is captured by the Queen of a crystal kingdom.  Aside from the poor animation & the Queen’s annoying voice this is a great episode.  A-Disc 524.  Safari Joe:  Safari Joe comes to Third Earth looking for prey 'worthy' of being hunted. He begins hunting the ThunderCats.  I always love episodes with hunters hunt down our heroes like animals, and this is no exception.  A+25.  Snarf Takes Up The Challenge:  After the ThunderCats are captured by Mumm-Ra, it is up to Snarf to save them.  A pretty good spotlight for Snarf.  B+26.  Sixth Sense:  A ship in trouble tries to ask the ThunderCats for help using Cheetara's sixth sense.  It ends up taking control of Cheetara and putting her life in danger as the mutants attack it.  Poor animation and a stupid plot make this one of the worst episodes.  D27. The Thunder-Cutter:  Lion-O meets Hachiman, a samurai from another world who wields a sword called the Thunder-Cutter.  Hachiman is one of the best guest characters.  There a couple plotholes (What happened to the ninja?) but it’s still a mostly excellent episode.  A28.  The Wolfrat:  Vulture Man builds a robot called the Wolfrat, which uses a miniaturization gas that reduces the ThunderCats to 9 inches high. They must rely on a normal size Snarf to help them defeat the robot.  A decent enough episode.  Though the “incredible shrinking” plots aren’t usually fantastic, they are better than the “frame the heroes” plot.  BDisc 629-30.  The Feliner:  Vulture Man summons the Mutant warlord known as Ratar-O who kidnaps Snarf's nephew, Snarfer on the planet of Snarfs.  Then they bring Snarfer back to Third Earth and use him as bait to trap the ThunderCats.  The show’s only 2 part story is great.  A31.  Mandora And The Pirates:  Mandora boards a space freighter for inspection. But it turns out to be the ancient space pirate ship, the Jolly Rogers and she needs Lion-O's help.  I actually liked this.  B+32.  Return of the Driller:  Mumm-Ra instructs the Driller to bore a tunnel from an acid lake to the Cats Lair. It's a race to save the Lair as they face obstacle after obstacle while trying to obtain and bring back a sponge cloud to fill the hole.  This is much better than the Driller’s first appearance.  A33.  Dimension Doom:  Wizz-Ra returns from the 7th dimension once every 7000 years, this time he enters Cat's Lair through a mirror in Cheetara's room. Mumm-Ra, his ancient enemy, is able to steal his magic helmet.  He then enslaves the Thundercats and only Cheetara and Snarf are left to help their new friend before his time runs out.  An excellent episode to end the volume on.  A+Most of the episodes ranged from A- to A+, & there were only 3 bad episodes.  I honestly believe this to be one of the greatest cartoons ever, so I expected nothing less.  I’m glad to see that there are many other people out there who agree with me.
summary: The best cat cartoon, next to SWAT Kats.

reviewText: While I'm glad to finally be able to get this iconic series from my childhood on dvd it's also a mixed blessing with some of the video quality the sets came out with too.  While it's not as bad as if you had the VHS version of the series it still shows its age as you see some graininess and lines in some of the scenes, not all but some. I can sort of understand though as it does cost a good deal of money to find and remaster the original film of the series and if the company is unsure if they will make enough of a profit on this franchise most businesses will just do the standard cleaning and dress up of a series like what was done with this set. While I still find the series enjoyable still many children might find the series a little cheesy for their taste as we have to remember there's about a twenty-five year gap when this series came out and the cartoons that children see today, so as pretty much expected these sets are mostly for the people who first saw the series when it first aired on t.v. sort of like series like G.I.Joe,The Smurfs,Ducktales,Captain N(If anyone remembers that saturday cartoon) and the like.  So for all us kids from the 80's here's an enjoyable set to let us remember those long past yester-years fondly but just don't expect the video and sound clarity we've gotten use to with other series like Family Guy or the CSI:Las Vegas series sets....
summary: Enjoyable For Us Who Grew Up With The Series But Not For The New Generation Probably
Title: N/A

reviewText: As a child of the 80's,  I grew up watching this series, partially because I liked the idea that cat people would save the galaxy from imminent danger.Having the first half of this season (1985) then is a must for anybody who wants a time when broadcast television cartoons had depth to them and did not condescend to their viewer's intelligence.In addition to a cool opening theme song, it's actually got plot.Lion-o is Lord and leader of the Thundercats, a band of cosmic cat travelers who has crashed on third earth. Despite his physical age (actually only approaching 20), Lion-o still has a lot of learning to do. He is guided (as are all the Thundercats) by the spirit of Jaga, who died in the escape from their exploding planet Thundera.Pumro is the mechanics whiz of the group who can build anything from anything. During the series run he builds the Thundertank (how many of the cats except Cheetara, obviously-travel) and the Feliner (a plane).Cheetara is really fast and has limited empathic capabilities with other beings which they encounter. Tygra is the other feline in the group. Wiley Kit and Wiley Kat are the kids who are both physically and mentally immature, I think they were supposed to be the characters for us kids to identify with.Snarf is Lion-o's nurse maid and the `team mascot', who occasionally saves them from harm (Snarf Takes Up The Challenge)  The awesome Cats Lair was built with the help of the friendly Berbills (Berbills) whom the Thundercats soon meet after landing on Third Earth.The Thundercats are set up against mutants who are under the command of the evil mummy Mumm-ra. Like all classic villains, Mumm-ra is determined to rule and exploit that world for his own selfish needs. It is up to the Thundercats to protect Third Earth against those plans. This cartoon is revolutionary because it also acknowledged that not everybody on Third Earth was enthralled with the Thundercats and even if they also opposed Mumm-ra, wanted to be left alone.In "The Micrits" the Thundercats learn that Micrits have unwillingly been drawn into their past battles and their homes ruined as the end result of both Mutants and Thundercats inevitably stepping on them during the course of battle. War has consequences and is not something which can done in isolation from the rest of society.Another important episode is "Return to Thundera". Lion-o gets to see his planet before it blows up by way of using a nuclear projection to visit the past. Lion-o also meets his father Claudius, whom he obviously did not otherwise have time to have a relationship with while still on Thundera. The Thundercat franchise was primarily marketed towards kids, but I am thinking that this series held cross generational appeal specifically because of the product quality in stories such as these.This animation was done when the computer age was relatively new, and thus the series still used line drawings, but the Thundercats genuinely does not look dated in any way. It actually is significantly better than a lot of the garbage which is being passed off as `cartoons' today. This series even has much less violence than many of today's cartoons combined, instead opting for mysticism,The price is really affordable considering how few other options there are for getting high-quality Thundercats episodes.I'm honestly disappointed it is only half of season one, but also count my blessings it came out at all. Because recently seeing this cartoon has been virtually impossible unless 20 something year old tapes were hoarded or bought from traders, this DVD release is a welcome development. Let's get more 80's cartoons ASAP.
summary: Great Thundera-this DVD set is a must get!

Title: N/A

reviewText: I hadn't seen Thundercats since I was a kid. With all my memories faded by time, I didn't know what to expect when I ordered this. I just remembered loving watching it as a kid.After a couple agonizing weeks of waiting for it to come in the mail, I couldn't wait to get that first DVD in and re-discover this show.With all the 80's shows that are coming out now, there have been some hit and miss releases for me. I'm an even bigger Transformers fan now than I was as a kid. He-Man has been totally ruined for me. Thundercats neither made me a fan-boy all over again nor did it disappoint me.Now as an adult, it struck me as being one of the most well written and well animated cartoons from the 80's.Like most cartoons from the 80's, it has its share of stock-animation, bad voice acting and PSA sermons. But Thundercats balances it out by having good animation (stock or otherwise), characters you fall in love with, and some of today's toons would probably do better to have a little more PSA sermons.The way I make it sound, Thundercats is just an 80's cartoon with the same 80's failings. But that's not necessarily a bad thing. Thundercats is still well written, well animated, deals with issues that are suprisingly mature for your typical 80's toon and bottom line, it's fun to watch.Skipping on the first episode: I only notice it once. It cannot be considered a major failing of this release.No music on second episode: doesn't ruin it for me personally. That doesn't affect the story in the least.With the problems I noted: voice acting isn't really steller at some points, glitches on first and second episodes; I can't give it a perfect score. However, Thundercats is still a great show. I definitely plan on buying the second set. It's well worth the price. So problems notwithstanding, this still rates very high with me.
Title: N/A

reviewText: You know, I've found in my re-viewings of shows I loved as a kid that some just don't hold up like they use to, the main problem I have with Thundercats is that it was always the SAME thing over and over, it was never really different, that just got old and boring super fast, and honestly, Mumm-Ra was NOT the greatest villain by any means, especially compared to the great Skeletor from He-Man and the Masters of the Universe. Don't worry, I have the same problem with He-Man and the Masters of the Universe as I do with Thundercats. that show was always the same thing too, at least there was a variety more of characters and villains than Thundercats. Setting my complaints of Thundercats aside, I did say that this set in particular was the best of the seasons I watched, and that is so. This season one, part one is excellent, an absolute blast as it was when I was a kid, if not, even better! This season held up great after all these years, and was really, really fun to watch again, I recommend it to fans of this show. This really was good and has a great and memorable song as well.Thundercats: Season One, Part One ****1/2 out of *****Violent Content: 3/10 - Action Violence.
summary: The only good part of the seasons!
Title: N/A

reviewText: Thundercats was one of the better series of the 1980's.  I will not dispute that in any way, shape, or form.BUT the quality of the audio/video is VERY much lacking.  The episodes were not remastered.  I might as well watch my old VHS tapes.  The sound quality is low as well.  It would seem to be mono, not stereo, sound.  Also, as one other person pointed out, the music is missing from one of the episodes.  That's a huge error.I'm sorry, but Warner Brothers? You made a huge mistake releasing it like this.  I'm incredibly disappointed.I recommend the rest of you go find the old VHS tapes, because they're cheaper than this and about the same quality.
summary: I do not dispute that the show itself is great, but the DVDs are a different story...
Title: N/A

reviewText: Thudercats is a great show I enjoyed watching as a child. Cartoon Network picked it up in 1997 and I got to see all those great shows all over again and I was surprised that they held up as well as they had. They weren't nearly as cheesy as they could have been. Thundercats isn't perfect, but it is better than a lot of what kids currently watch. The animation is actually quite good, as well as the music. The stories aren't bad and still manage to entertain. (And hey, any cartoon with a Devil Priest as the main villain has to be good - you'll never see that in a kids' show these days - Hail Mumm-Ra!)Once the DVD format came out and TV shows started being released, I couldn't wait to own Thundercats, just as soon as they were available. The transfers are pretty clean and the menus are good. Overall the producers did well. The only real problem I have, and apparently others I've heard from, is that some of the episodes have the music omitted, dialogue and sound effects are intact. Only the second episode had this problem for me, but I'm only halfway through the set. As far as the others, I'll just have to see - other buyers should point out if their discs have similar problems. However, this drawback isn't enough to warrant a bad rating. If you enjoyed this show as a kid - get this set.Update - The star rating was dropped by one from my previous score. Not due to the content of the show, but due to the quality of the DVD transfer. Music is missing from key episodes and dramatically affects the presentation. Also, the first episodes are edited from their original airings. Not much is cut, but enough that I noticed pieces of the show were missing and made me glad I still have some of these shows recorded on Betamax. (God I feel old)
summary: Great cartoon from back in the day
Title: N/A

reviewText: I was prepared to scratch another childhood favorite off of my list. With great excitement, I opened my new Thundercats DVD's and put the first one in. My stomach churned just a bit as it loaded. Then it happened.Grainy images, comparable to the Zapruder film in both in their quality and sadness, filled my screen... and that was just the menu loading. I hoped beyond all reason that it was just the menu, but no. As the first episode began to play, with it's muffled sound and an image quality that looked like it was copied straight from a VCR... a Beta-max VCR, I felt my head become as light as my wallet. The inclusion of a short featurette exploiting a few Thundercats fans and Will Wheaton (Who must not have seen a preview copy of the DVD's) does not make up for this 3rd world rush job.Don't hold your breath waiting for this series to get the proper treatment. No way they go back and re-do these on this format. And I suspect that season 2, already in the pipe-line, won't fare any better. My advice? Wait until some poor soul sells theirs out of spite and get them used. The stories are as good as ever, the presentation however leaves much to be desired.To paraphrase Lion-O. "Thundercats, no!"

reviewText: I just wanted to let all the people who are considering purchasing this DVD set to know that it is NOT worth your money.  I was hoping that by wating to buy my set from a new shipment the problems of the audio and video would have been fixed, but that is NOT the case.  WB just keeps sending retailers the botched DVD sets rather than recalling them from warehouses and replacing them with a quality set that is worth the $50+  price tag.  If I were you, I would see what happens when set 1 and 2 are released together in December, maybe by then WB will have fixed the mass problems with set 1.I just found the number to call if you purchased the DVD with a bad disk 1. Call 800-553-6937 for a replacement or go to [...]
summary: Great Show, But WB has botched this one.  Buyer Beware!
